An Irish paper gives the following anecdote of
the simplicity ofa raw Pat who had just been trans
planted from the interior to Dublin. Pat had been
sent by his mastert to purchase half-a-bushe otoys-
ters, on the quay but was absent long, that ap-
prehensons were entertained for his safety. lie
returned at last however putting under his load in
the most musical STYLE Where the devil have
you been ? exclaimed his master. sWhere have
been why where would be but to fetch the oys-
ters!' and what, in the name of ST. Patrick kept
you SO long," Long! by my soapl think have
been pretty quick considering all things Conslde.
ring what things p Considering what things
Why considering the guttingof the fish, to be sure'
Cutting what fish 2 what fish why, blur anowns
the oysters to be sure!' sWhat do you mean I?
what do | name % Why, name, that was a
resting myselfdown forenent the Picked herring,
and having drop to comfort me jontleman axed
what had got in the sack? Oysters, says !. 'Lets
look at them,'. says he; and he opens the bag.
Och thunder and praties, says he, 'who sould you
lhese? 1T was Mick Carney says i-'board the
Fowl hoodie smack mick Carney the thieto the
worldn says he what a blackguard he must be to
give them to you without cutting And ar'nt they
Quilted ? says |. sDeal o. one Them says he.
,Mesha, then, says |, 'swhat will do ? 'Do,' says
ne, "Pd sooner do it for you myself than have you
abused ! and so he takes'em in doors and CUTS EN-
aate and clane, as you'll sce opening at the same
''me his bag of oyster shells, which were as empty
as the head that bore them to the house. II we had
not this from an Irish paper, we should entertain
doubts Of its authenticity.


We have heard of the above story being located
10 Boston twenty years ago-Which nation has tho
credit Of it Ed. Chronicle.

ANECDOTE.

years old, hnw can it be expected faithfully to
tain all the points in conversations which took place
50 long ago as 1892 When, therefore, Gen. jack
sons implied admission, that some conversation did
take place, is coupled with the known in6delity Of
his memory, his denial that it was ''such conver-
saton as stated to have taken place." will as the
Editors Of the Enquirer pre-suppose, require colla-
teral evidence to support it.


The Editors Of the Enquirer ask, sswhat were
the friends of General Jackson to do under these
circumstances? Were they to let the calunlny
sweep over the country uncontradicted-or were
they to seek the truth where it was to be found
We will answer the question. II they knew Gen.
Jackson to be innocent, it was their duty TO arrest
the calumny at once and effectively. They should
have sought he truth were it to be found. "vlz:
Of Mr.. Tazewell and Mr.. Tyler, who were referred
TO- II is true the Enquirer says that MIR. Tyler
.'denes all personal knowledge Of the transaction"
This is as equivocal denial as that Of General
/ Jackson himself Will Mr. Tyler and Mr.. Tsze-
we'll say that the menace was not matter OF notorl-
ETY. in Washington, and that the feeling it excited
was not general? VIII they say that it is not we'll
known that the execution of the menace was pre-
vented by the interference Of Commodore DECATUR
AS to the quibbing about the precise terms OF =
conversation. and the place where it was held, we
deem it altogether unworthy Of a man seeking the
highest dignity in the country, and lying under an
lInputation which, his own friends acknowledge,
.'touches his honor most nearly"

FOR. 1928.

Our readers will recollect the statement which has
appeared in many papers. charging General Jackson
with threatening to cut off the ears of certain Sen
ators of the United States, who, in the exercise Of
their constitutional duties, had severely commented
on some parts Of his conduct during the Seminole
War. The details as to the course General Jack
son adopted to carry his menace into execution,
and the interference Of Commodore Decature, have
been given to the world several weeks ago. Mr.
From the National Journal.

WASHINGTON, Monday eve, Dec. !.


Dear Sir-I perceive that you have thought Mr..
Sanford's vote the subject of the Senate printing,
censurabe. Displeased as am at the result OF that
matter, do not think MIR. Sanford can in any way
be charged with declared partiaty for Duff Green.
His vote has been misunderstood You will pro-
badly recollect that Mr.. Clayton introduced last
year. when this subject under discussion. re-
solution establishing that maj rlty OF the Senators
present should be necessary Tor the election OF a
printer. Duff Green on that occasion had plural
tv of the votes, and after several ballots, further
proceedings on the subject was suspended, ON mo-


lion of MIR. Benton. On the FIRST occasion tor print
ing, this session. it observed by Mr.. Eaton
that there was as yet no printer He then intro
Guced resolution hat Duff Green. having last year
received plurality of votes. was du' elected un-
der the joint resolution of the two houess passed III
49, 9. On this resolution debate arose. 1t was
contended on one side. By Messrs. Eaton. Benton,
and Hayne, that the joint resolution of 1919 was
still in full force providing for the manner IN which
the work should be done, the securities &c. and
that the person having the greatest number OF votes
should be elected that the Senate last year. order
ed the election to take place in pursuance Of the
rule of 1919; that on the day appointed tor the ell
ection, that rule was modified in one particular
alone, that is, making majority necessary TO a
| choice, And they further contended that the rule
of l8l9 if obligatory in one respect, was obligatory
in all and hence it was not in the power Of the
Senate to cause the modification without the consent
Of the House, which had been party to the original
rule. The resolution offered by MIR. Clayton and
adopted last year. being thus nugatory, it followed
that the election was duly made under the order Of
the 18th Of last February for the election, made III
pursuance of the rule of 1919.


On the other side it was urged by Messrs. Cham
bers, Robbins and Macon, that the joint resolution
uf 1919 was dead, having been framed, as its words
implied, only for particular season that the reso-
luton of MIR. Clayton was deliberately adopted,
and under it, the Senate proceeded to its elec-
ton that election having been made on the first,
second and third ballots, the baoting was suspend
ed not upon the ground Of irregularity, but because
it was inconvenient to go on-no objection being Of
lered until the third ballot to the rm OF proceeding;
consequently no election was made, which was Il n
generally understood.


rhe question then occurred upon Mr.. Eaton's re-
solution, which was adopted by vote of 25 to l9,
MIR Sanford and Mr.. Barton of the administration
party voting for it, and MIR. Macon of the opposi-
tion against it.


Thus you will perceive that the bare question de-
cded by this vote did not involve an expression of
either personal or party predictions. 1t was the
simple proposition whether the joint resolution OF
1919 was still in full force and it being declared
to be so, there call upon the Senators to de-
signate their favourte printer by name Under
these circumstances it appears to me that there
might be conscientious dsagreements. Mr.. Bar
ton, also, who voted for MIR. Eton's resolution, is
firm friend of the administration, and Of Gales &
SeatoD,

From the NcW York Amer,ean.


[From our C Correspondent

Chamomile flowers are seryiceable as a tonic
in loss OF appetite, dyspepsia, &c. are an antspasmo
die well suited to debility conseque nty, !,
preferable to the nauseous Indian weed (say moth
ing OF the disgusting effluva ofthe latter nasmuch
as swallowing the saliva is wholesome and beneficial
TO the constitution, whereas, parting with it is deb-
itating and injurious.


| only recommend to those who have unconscious
ty become welded to the loathsome practice of
chewing tobacco, and who wish to wean themselves
from it, equally unconsciously, to make trial of the
Chamomile they will very soon become accuston,-
ed to the taste, (Which not dsasreeable) and find
themselves much benefited by the change. Parting
with the saliva assists indigestion, creates thirst:
thus we almost invariably iud inyeterate to-
bacco chewer, an inclination 10 drink often. | at
tribute the besettlng sin of drunkenness, ID grea,
measure to the free oftobacco, for the two vi
ces seem to be inseparabe in great degree, as
there is hardly drunkard in thousand, who is
| not tobacco chewer. As have touched upon the
runous and growing evil, drunkenness, or drinking
to excessl II may be meet at this time to prescribe
for that, ylz;-A cup of hot coffee at II o'clock
instead of stiff glass of brandy and water Spirit
uous liquors when first taken produce agreeable
and pleasant effect the system, but that effec
soon yanishes, and leaves the patient much more de
bilitated. hence the hankering for more to restore
him to his wonted spirits, Coffee promotes diges
ton, nourishes and strengthens the system, and NJ
danger can be apprehended from its frequent use


it can be obtained now at all hours, at the most
spectacle grog shops, beg pardon, refectories i
the city.


|

From " Sibyi Leaves," by Edmund Readr.
uars through twilight closters stealing
Faint the sounds Of music roll;
IT'S the solemn requiem pealing,


Breathed for departed soul.
Distant now the voices blending,


Through the dim aisles iioa,ing stray,
Like incense to Heaven ascending,


Bearing soul and sense away!
Now the notes on frailty dwelling,


Low and trembling are preferred
Now in ia,t and triumph swelling,


High, as if their God had heard.
Now again they die-bcrcaying
Hope Of dreams round which it twlned,
Gone are loves wild VISIONS, leaving


Tears, and weight Of earth behind.
THE REQUIEM.

Mr.. misunderstanding in your paper The yeas
and nayson the question of Offering vote of thanks
by Congress to the immortal Washington, and fin
ding the name of Andrew jackson recorded in oppo"
sition thereto, have made up my mind to vote
against him. A man who was the enemy of the fa-
ther of his country, the great and good Washir,-
ton, ought not to be permitted to occupy his seat.


A LATE JACKSONIAN.
Nov. 23, 1877

CURE FOR TOBACCO CHEWERS.


Having recently discovered a remedy for the
above mentioned disgraceful practice, hasten to
make public mot deeming it practicable to secure
apatent and shall consider myself abun'antly com.

From the Baltimore Patriot.
CURE FOR TOBACCO CHEWERs

Prison Discipline Society, formed in Boston,


June 80, 1895.


Object, to promote the improvement of Public
Prisons, particularly within the United States. A
very extensive examination into the state of prisons
throughout the country, has shown the evils exist
ing IN them TO be enormous and that, too general
ly, they are, instead of correctives the very
ries OF vice. Perhaps the most prominent evil is,
that OF vicious men being brought together in great
numbers, especially at night to teach one another
lniqulty, and harden one another in sin. The con-
sequence OF this has been, that the prisoner when
released, has, in too many instances gone forth on
ly to commit new outrages and that very large
portion of convicts have consisted of those who have
been recommtted. The State prison recently es-
tablished at .auburn, N. York. one which this So
ciety recommend Z" model worthy ofthe world
imitation some of the characteristics of which are
the following neaness, industry, and the almost
entire subordinaon and subdued feeling Of the con-
yicts. In their solitary cells, they spend the night
| with no other book but the Bible; and at sunrise,
| they proceed, in military order with the lock
march, to their workshops thence, in the same
order to the common hall, where they partake Of
their frugal meal in silence. Not even whisper is
hhard. The convicts are seated in single file, al
narrow tables, with their backs towards the centre
so that there can be no interchange Of signs From
end of the shop to the other, you may pass SOC
convcts without seeing one leave his work. or turn
his head to gaze. They attend to their business
from morning to night the work is laid aside al
at once, and the convicts return in military order
to their solitary cells where they can, if they
choose, read the Scriptures undisturbed, and ther
reflect, in silence, the errors of theirlives. They
must not disturb their fellow prisoners by even ;
whisper. Each cell is provided with Bible, OF
Testament, by law of the State. The prisoners
also receive the undivided attention of wise ant
faithful and religious teacher, who spends all hi
time in the prison visiting the sick, teaching those


who cannot read, preaching in the chapel, ON th'
i Sabbath, the unsearchable riches of Christ, ant
going from cell to cell to administer the reproof


and consultations of religion to individuals. In thi
prison there is exclusion of all the positive evil
of the old SYSTEM which arise from cro1yded rooms
pick pockets, tieves ancendiares, and co,nteeiters
' and from unnatural crime.-A number ofnew pri


sons already erecting on the plan of that at Au
burn, and it may be confidently hoped, that mos
= salutary reform will ultimately be effected in tn
general system of Prison Discipline


y We are informed (says the Kentucky Reporter,
d that the following members who voted for Mr
n Ward the Jackson candidate for Speaker, con


sidered by their constituents, Administration men
d when they were elected viz =


e Messrs. Henderson, Bishop, Munford, Hall ant


Davis And two or three others, whose names ar


not recollected

by the Richmond Enquirer as (which most near
y touches the character Of Gen. Jackson, next to
the honor Of his wife.'' It


The charge thus admitted to be of the most ser- h
GUS character, would if unfounded, according to the
ordinary course and operations Of human feeling,
have been promptly met by stern and explicit de-
NAL. Mr.. Tyler and Mr.. razewel reside within
three days journey OF the OF the accusation
One OF them is the Jealous partzan o General jack
son, and be presu ned to be sensitiyey alive to
every rumor which could affect the honor and pros
poets OF him under whose banner he has marshaed.
They were both appealed to as witnesses. Yet they
preserve an nhexibe silence: and the Editors Of
the Richmond Enquirer, instead Of applying to their
neighbors. or having applied. perhaps instead OF
publishing their testimony, procure one OF General
Jack,O 'sfriends in the :itv of Rich nond, who AL
many friends and acquaintances in ne State Of
Tennessee "to ascertain, it he could, the real state
of the case, in relation to this celebrated Story"
Now, whether g friends and acquaintances in the
State of Tennessee" were better qualified to
give the ''real state Of the case'' than MIR Tyler
and .,ir. Tazewell, who said to have been at
Washington at the time, our readers are as well
able to decide as we are


BE this as it may, the application is made in Ten
nessee to OBJ ain 'she real state of the case, in
der that it might be laid before the worlds" and the
result is the publication Of letter from Felix Grun
dy to General jackson, and the reply of the General
and this reply is given to us by the Enquirer as con-
tanning the cal state Of the case" We subjoin
the two letters


NASHVILLE, Nov. 18th, 1927.


Dear sr-On this day received letter from friend
Of mine in Richmond, (va.) requesting to ascertain


from you, whether there is amy foundation III truth, i'll Ger
tain statements circulated in that section Of country
specng conversation alledgcd to have taken place be
tween Commodore Decatur AMI yourself. in the anti


chamber of the Senate, in the year 1919. understand
the Charge made against you, s-1hat the last night
of the session, you, accompanied by your aids de
the nber the Senate, while
there Conmodore Decatur up to you and inquired
whether you there for the purpose of castising Mr.


Eppes &c. To which replied atfiimatlyey and at


ter further remarks, you declared your determination
to chastisc Mr. Eppes the Senate Chamber where he
had sandered you-and Commodore Decatur stated tha


should enter the Senate door but his dead b0d


In short you agreed desst from purpose, &c


BE obiging to furnish an answer as early as con
,enient. FELIX GRUNDY.
Gen. ANDREW JACKSON.


NASHVILLE Tss Nov 15th 1927.


Dear Sir Your letter of this day has been cevcd


and hasten answerit it. The statement to which you al
ude is wholly destitute of truth. was net in the Senate
Chamber antichambcr in the year 1879. My aidsde


camp General Call and Captain Easter The forme


is still living and will satisfy any person who will inquire OF
hm that the statement is Untrue As to Commodore D.


and myself having such conversation stated to


have taken place in the antichamber of the Senate,
had such conversation there elsewhere. Com
e modore Decatur and myself We're friendly at all times,


and harsh unkind expressions passed from
to the other. So far from my visiting the Senate Cham


ber invited to do by several OF the members OF


that body decned doing and assigned my reasons for
n my conduct,


lam, very respectfully, your most obedent servant.
ANDREW JACKSON.
n The Hon. +. GnuNnY, Esq.


$ As the Editors of the Enquirer are astonishingy
u acute to the subject of episolary phrase it may be


scarcely necessary to point out to their conviction
the omissions in this correspondence. But it is ne


cessary to remove all misness front the public mind
y and let the truth shine out, unclouded. We aver,
therefore, that the correspondence which we have
Y quoted instead of refuting the charge, confirms it, in
: our opinion, in its principal point. 1t will be seen
q that the letter of Mr. Grundy, the language ofwhict
IS evidently the result of previous consultation
e with General Jackson blinks the main charge-the
menace to cut off the ofa Senator for the manly
a discharge Of his constitutional dutyand relates
IS clusivey to the minor matter of the character and
is the locality of the conversation between the Gene
Is raj and Commodore Decatur.-The question put
!; by Mr.. Grundy is : Whether there is any founda
y ton in truth, in certain statements respecting
$; versation alledged to have taken place betwee.
l. Commodore Decatur and yourself, in the an-cham
l. ber of the Senate in the year 1919 % The reply
81 of the General is "As to Commodore Decatur and
myself having sach conversation stated to have a


ken place in the anti-chamber of the Senate, me-


yer had such conversation there or elsewhere y
y The natural inference from this choice and repeti
r. ton of the phrase such conversation" is that
l. they had conversation the subject, but it was
q, not "such conversation as mas Deen reported


Recent disclosures must have satisfied every one
ID that the memory of General jackson is not always
e faithful. We state this, not as an impuation on


his character, but fact growing out OF the nr-


mites of age If time has left untouched the viva


city of his ambition. and the arlor of his passions,


it has manfestly impaired his faculty of recollec-
IS ton. Of this the Editors of the Enquirer show
N themselves to be aware when they admit the neces
sty of corroboralng letter from General Call. to
If sustain the "reminiscences of the General. The


facts which have lately transpired from the letters of

the simplicity ofa raw Pat who had just been trans
planted from the interior to Dublin. Pat had been
sent by his mastert to purchase half-a-bushe otoys-
ters, on the quay but was absent long, that ap-

returned at last however putting under his load in
the most musical STYLE Where the devil have
you been ? exclaimed his master. sWhere have
been why where would be but to fetch the oys-
ters!' and what, in the name of ST. Patrick kept
you SO long," Long! by my soapl think have
been pretty quick considering all things Conslde.
ring what things p Considering what things
Why considering the guttingof the fish, to be sure'
Cutting what fish 2 what fish why, blur anowns
the oysters to be sure!' sWhat do you mean I?
what do | name % Why, name, that was a
resting myselfdown forenent the Picked herring,
and having drop to comfort me jontleman axed
what had got in the sack? Oysters, says !. 'Lets
look at them,'. says he; and he opens the bag.
Och thunder and praties, says he, 'who sould you
lhese? 1T was Mick Carney says i-'board the
Fowl hoodie smack mick Carney the thieto the
worldn says he what a blackguard he must be to
give them to you without cutting And ar'nt they
Quilted ? says |. sDeal o. one Them says he.
,Mesha, then, says |, 'swhat will do ? 'Do,' says
ne, "Pd sooner do it for you myself than have you
abused ! and so he takes'em in doors and CUTS EN-
aate and clane, as you'll sce opening at the same
''me his bag of oyster shells, which were as empty
as the head that bore them to the house. II we had
not this from an Irish paper, we should entertain
doubts Of its authenticity.

contended on one side. By Messrs. Eaton. Benton,
and Hayne, that the joint resolution of 1919 was
still in full force providing for the manner IN which
the work should be done, the securities &c. and
that the person having the greatest number OF votes
should be elected that the Senate last year. order
ed the election to take place in pursuance Of the
rule of 1919; that on the day appointed tor the ell
ection, that rule was modified in one particular
alone, that is, making majority necessary TO a
| choice, And they further contended that the rule
of l8l9 if obligatory in one respect, was obligatory
in all and hence it was not in the power Of the
Senate to cause the modification without the consent
Of the House, which had been party to the original
rule. The resolution offered by MIR. Clayton and
adopted last year. being thus nugatory, it followed
that the election was duly made under the order Of
the 18th Of last February for the election, made III
pursuance of the rule of 1919.


On the other side it was urged by Messrs. Cham
bers, Robbins and Macon, that the joint resolution
uf 1919 was dead, having been framed, as its words
implied, only for particular season that the reso-
luton of MIR. Clayton was deliberately adopted,
and under it, the Senate proceeded to its elec-
ton that election having been made on the first,
second and third ballots, the baoting was suspend
ed not upon the ground Of irregularity, but because
it was inconvenient to go on-no objection being Of
lered until the third ballot to the rm OF proceeding;
consequently no election was made, which was Il n
generally understood.


rhe question then occurred upon Mr.. Eaton's re-
solution, which was adopted by vote of 25 to l9,
MIR Sanford and Mr.. Barton of the administration
party voting for it, and MIR. Macon of the opposi-
tion against it.


Thus you will perceive that the bare question de-
cded by this vote did not involve an expression of
either personal or party predictions. 1t was the
simple proposition whether the joint resolution OF
1919 was still in full force and it being declared
to be so, there call upon the Senators to de-
signate their favourte printer by name Under
these circumstances it appears to me that there
might be conscientious dsagreements. Mr.. Bar
ton, also, who voted for MIR. Eton's resolution, is
firm friend of the administration, and Of Gales &
SeatoD,

bacco chewer, an inclination 10 drink often. | at

ces seem to be inseparabe in great degree, as

uous liquors when first taken produce agreeable

full articles.headline: THE REQUIEM.
full articles.article:
From " Sibyi Leaves," by Edmund Readr.
uars through twilight closters stealing
Faint the sounds Of music roll;
IT'S the solemn requiem pealing,


Breathed for departed soul.
Distant now the voices blending,


Through the dim aisles iioa,ing stray,
Like incense to Heaven ascending,


Bearing soul and sense away!
Now the notes on frailty dwelling,


Low and trembling are preferred
Now in ia,t and triumph swelling,


High, as if their God had heard.
Now again they die-bcrcaying
Hope Of dreams round which it twlned,
Gone are loves wild VISIONS, leaving


Tears, and weight Of earth behind.

full articles.headline: From the Wester', Herald.
full articles.article:
Mr.. misunderstanding in your paper The yeas
and nayson the question of Offering vote of thanks
by Congress to the immortal Washington, and fin
ding the name of Andrew jackson recorded in oppo"
sition thereto, have made up my mind to vote
against him. A man who was the enemy of the fa-
ther of his country, the great and good Washir,-
ton, ought not to be permitted to occupy his seat.


A LATE JACKSONIAN.
Nov. 23, 1877

CURE FOR TOBACCO CHEWERS.


Having recently discovered a remedy for the
above mentioned disgraceful practice, hasten to
make public mot deeming it practicable to secure
apatent and shall consider myself abun'antly com.
pensated, should it be the means of checking this

full articles.headline:
Prison Discipline Society, formed in Boston,


June 80, 1895.
full articles.article:
Prison Discipline Society, formed in Boston,


June 80, 1895.


Object, to promote the improvement of Public
Prisons, particularly within the United States. A
very extensive examination into the state of prisons
throughout the country, has shown the evils exist
ing IN them TO be enormous and that, too general
ly, they are, instead of correctives the very
ries OF vice. Perhaps the most prominent evil is,
that OF vicious men being brought together in great
numbers, especially at night to teach one another
lniqulty, and harden one another in sin. The con-
sequence OF this has been, that the prisoner when
released, has, in too many instances gone forth on
ly to commit new outrages and that very large
portion of convicts have consisted of those who have
been recommtted. The State prison recently es-
tablished at .auburn, N. York. one which this So
ciety recommend Z" model worthy ofthe world
imitation some of the characteristics of which are
the following neaness, industry, and the almost
entire subordinaon and subdued feeling Of the con-
yicts. In their solitary cells, they spend the night
| with no other book but the Bible; and at sunrise,
| they proceed, in military order with the lock
march, to their workshops thence, in the same
order to the common hall, where they partake Of
their frugal meal in silence. Not even whisper is
hhard. The convicts are seated in single file, al
narrow tables, with their backs towards the centre
so that there can be no interchange Of signs From
end of the shop to the other, you may pass SOC
convcts without seeing one leave his work. or turn
his head to gaze. They attend to their business
from morning to night the work is laid aside al
at once, and the convicts return in military order
to their solitary cells where they can, if they
choose, read the Scriptures undisturbed, and ther
reflect, in silence, the errors of theirlives. They
must not disturb their fellow prisoners by even ;
whisper. Each cell is provided with Bible, OF
Testament, by law of the State. The prisoners
also receive the undivided attention of wise ant
faithful and religious teacher, who spends all hi
time in the prison visiting the sick, teaching those


who cannot read, preaching in the chapel, ON th'
i Sabbath, the unsearchable riches of Christ, ant
going from cell to cell to administer the reproof


and consultations of religion to individuals. In thi
prison there is exclusion of all the positive evil
of the old SYSTEM which arise from cro1yded rooms
pick pockets, tieves ancendiares, and co,nteeiters
' and from unnatural crime.-A number ofnew pri


sons already erecting on the plan of that at Au
burn, and it may be confidently hoped, that mos
= salutary reform will ultimately be effected in tn
general system of Prison Discipline


y We are informed (says the Kentucky Reporter,
d that the following members who voted for Mr
n Ward the Jackson candidate for Speaker, con


sidered by their constituents, Administration men
d when they were elected viz =


e Messrs. Henderson, Bishop, Munford, Hall ant


Davis And two or three others, whose names ar


not recollected

by the Richmond Enquirer as (which most near
y touches the character Of Gen. Jackson, next to
the honor Of his wife.'' It


The charge thus admitted to be of the most ser- h
GUS character, would if unfounded, according to the
ordinary course and operations Of human feeling,
have been promptly met by stern and explicit de-
NAL. Mr.. Tyler and Mr.. razewel reside within
three days journey OF the OF the accusation
One OF them is the Jealous partzan o General jack
son, and be presu ned to be sensitiyey alive to
every rumor which could affect the honor and pros
poets OF him under whose banner he has marshaed.
They were both appealed to as witnesses. Yet they
preserve an nhexibe silence: and the Editors Of
the Richmond Enquirer, instead Of applying to their
neighbors. or having applied. perhaps instead OF
publishing their testimony, procure one OF General
Jack,O 'sfriends in the :itv of Rich nond, who AL
many friends and acquaintances in ne State Of
Tennessee "to ascertain, it he could, the real state
of the case, in relation to this celebrated Story"
Now, whether g friends and acquaintances in the
State of Tennessee" were better qualified to
give the ''real state Of the case'' than MIR Tyler
and .,ir. Tazewell, who said to have been at
Washington at the time, our readers are as well
able to decide as we are


BE this as it may, the application is made in Ten
nessee to OBJ ain 'she real state of the case, in
der that it might be laid before the worlds" and the
result is the publication Of letter from Felix Grun
dy to General jackson, and the reply of the General
and this reply is given to us by the Enquirer as con-
tanning the cal state Of the case" We subjoin
the two letters


NASHVILLE, Nov. 18th, 1927.


Dear sr-On this day received letter from friend
Of mine in Richmond, (va.) requesting to ascertain


from you, whether there is amy foundation III truth, i'll Ger
tain statements circulated in that section Of country
specng conversation alledgcd to have taken place be
tween Commodore Decatur AMI yourself. in the anti


chamber of the Senate, in the year 1919. understand
the Charge made against you, s-1hat the last night
of the session, you, accompanied by your aids de
the nber the Senate, while
there Conmodore Decatur up to you and inquired
whether you there for the purpose of castising Mr.


Eppes &c. To which replied atfiimatlyey and at


ter further remarks, you declared your determination
to chastisc Mr. Eppes the Senate Chamber where he
had sandered you-and Commodore Decatur stated tha


should enter the Senate door but his dead b0d


In short you agreed desst from purpose, &c


BE obiging to furnish an answer as early as con
,enient. FELIX GRUNDY.
Gen. ANDREW JACKSON.


NASHVILLE Tss Nov 15th 1927.


Dear Sir Your letter of this day has been cevcd


and hasten answerit it. The statement to which you al
ude is wholly destitute of truth. was net in the Senate
Chamber antichambcr in the year 1879. My aidsde


camp General Call and Captain Easter The forme


is still living and will satisfy any person who will inquire OF
hm that the statement is Untrue As to Commodore D.


and myself having such conversation stated to


have taken place in the antichamber of the Senate,
had such conversation there elsewhere. Com
e modore Decatur and myself We're friendly at all times,


and harsh unkind expressions passed from
to the other. So far from my visiting the Senate Cham


ber invited to do by several OF the members OF


that body decned doing and assigned my reasons for
n my conduct,


lam, very respectfully, your most obedent servant.
ANDREW JACKSON.
n The Hon. +. GnuNnY, Esq.


$ As the Editors of the Enquirer are astonishingy
u acute to the subject of episolary phrase it may be


scarcely necessary to point out to their conviction
the omissions in this correspondence. But it is ne


cessary to remove all misness front the public mind
y and let the truth shine out, unclouded. We aver,
therefore, that the correspondence which we have
Y quoted instead of refuting the charge, confirms it, in
: our opinion, in its principal point. 1t will be seen
q that the letter of Mr. Grundy, the language ofwhict
IS evidently the result of previous consultation
e with General Jackson blinks the main charge-the
menace to cut off the ofa Senator for the manly
a discharge Of his constitutional dutyand relates
IS clusivey to the minor matter of the character and
is the locality of the conversation between the Gene
Is raj and Commodore Decatur.-The question put
!; by Mr.. Grundy is : Whether there is any founda
y ton in truth, in certain statements respecting
$; versation alledged to have taken place betwee.
l. Commodore Decatur and yourself, in the an-cham
l. ber of the Senate in the year 1919 % The reply
81 of the General is "As to Commodore Decatur and
myself having sach conversation stated to have a


ken place in the anti-chamber of the Senate, me-


yer had such conversation there or elsewhere y
y The natural inference from this choice and repeti
r. ton of the phrase such conversation" is that
l. they had conversation the subject, but it was
q, not "such conversation as mas Deen reported


Recent disclosures must have satisfied every one
ID that the memory of General jackson is not always
e faithful. We state this, not as an impuation on


his character, but fact growing out OF the nr-


mites of age If time has left untouched the viva


city of his ambition. and the arlor of his passions,


it has manfestly impaired his faculty of recollec-
IS ton. Of this the Editors of the Enquirer show
N themselves to be aware when they admit the neces
sty of corroboralng letter from General Call. to
If sustain the "reminiscences of the General. The


facts which have lately transpired from the letters of
